Inferring topology of quantum phase space

Leonid Polterovich a
with an appendix by Laurent Charles
Abstract

Does a semiclassical particle remember the phase space topology? We discuss this question in the context of the Berezin-Toeplitz quantization and quantum measurement theory by using tools of topological data analysis. One of its facets involves a calculus of Toeplitz operators with piecewise constant symbol developed in an appendix by Laurent Charles.

1 Introduction

We discuss an application of persistent homology to quantum-classical correspondence, a fundamental principle stating that quantum mechanics contains classical one as the limiting case when the Planck constant â„Planck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar tends to 00. Paraphrasing [22, Chapter 7], this means that in this limit, mathematical structures of Hamiltonian dynamics on closed symplectic manifolds are hidden somewhere in the linear algebra and probability of matrix quantum mechanics. While a vast literature explores quantum footprints of dynamical phenomena such as transition to chaos [22], not much is known about the ones of phase space topology. In fact, on the quantum side, topological phenomena can be elusive. For instance, according to the tunneling effect [17], a quantum particle may commute between different connected components of an energy level set in the phase space, thus getting wrong about topology of this set.

In the present note we make a step towards understanding quantum footprints of phase space topology in the framework of quantum measurement theory. We deal with the following problem. Suppose that the phase space of a semiclassical system is equipped with a finite collection of sensors. An experimentalist, having an access to an ensemble of particles, registers each of them at a â€œnearbyâ€ sensor and gathers the statistics. Is it possible to guess homology of the phase space on the basis of the data obtained? We shall show, within a specific probabilistic model of registration, that such a topological inference is feasible provided the sensors form a sufficiently dense net in the phase space and the experimentalist can tune the range of the sensors. Roughly speaking, a sensor zğ‘§z has range ağ‘a if it cannot detect particles located at distance â‰¥aabsentğ‘\geq a from zğ‘§z. Here is a sketch of the proposed recipe.

  • 1.

    Take two special values of the range, a<bğ‘ğ‘a<b, which depend on local geometry of the sensor network, and which are assumed to be known in advance. Then, for each value of the range sâˆˆ{a,b}ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘s\in\{a,b\} perform two consecutive registrations and calculate, for all distinct sensors zğ‘§z and wğ‘¤w, the probability pzâ€‹w,ssubscriptğ‘ğ‘§ğ‘¤ğ‘ p_{zw,s} of registration at zğ‘§z and wğ‘¤w.

  • 2.

    Fix real m>0ğ‘š0m>0. Form a pair of simplicial complexes Qssubscriptğ‘„ğ‘ Q_{s}, sâˆˆ{a,b}ğ‘ ğ‘ğ‘s\in\{a,b\} whose vertices are the sensors, and whose simplices are formed by subsets Ïƒğœ\sigma of the vertices with pzâ€‹w,s>â„msubscriptğ‘ğ‘§ğ‘¤ğ‘ superscriptPlanck-constant-over-2-piğ‘šp_{zw,s}>\hbar^{m} for all distinct z,wâˆˆÏƒğ‘§ğ‘¤ğœz,w\in\sigma. Here we assume that the Planck constant â„Planck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar is small enough.

  • 3.

    With a right choice of ağ‘a and bğ‘b, Qasubscriptğ‘„ğ‘Q_{a} will be a subset of Qbsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘Q_{b}. The image of the inclusion morphism in homology Hâ€‹(Qa)â†’Hâ€‹(Qb)â†’ğ»subscriptğ‘„ğ‘ğ»subscriptğ‘„ğ‘H(Q_{a})\to H(Q_{b}) turns out to be isomorphic to the homology of the phase space.

For a rigorous statement, see Theorem 3.3 which is formulated in Section 3 and proved in Section 4. These sections contain brief preliminaries on persistent homology and relevant methods of topological data analysis. The mathematical model of registration is discussed in Sections 2 and 5. Section 6 discusses a possible strategy of inferring the homotopy type of the phase space. It involves a calculus of Toeplitz operators with piecewise constant symbol developed in an appendix by Laurent Charles. The note ends with an outline of further directions. Let us pass to precise formulations.

4 Persistent homology: proofs

We shall proof Theorem 3.3 in three steps: first, we compare the complex Qm,â„,Ïµsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘šPlanck-constant-over-2-piitalic-ÏµQ_{m,\hbar,\epsilon} with its classical analogue, next we observe that the latter is in some sense close to the Vietoris-Rips complex of the sensor network Zğ‘Z, and finally we deduce the theorem by using methods of topological data analysis.

4.4 Discussion: do we really need barcodes?

Denote by Î“âŠ‚â„+Î“subscriptâ„\Gamma\subset{\mathbb{R}}_{+} the finite set of all distances dâ€‹(z,w)ğ‘‘ğ‘§ğ‘¤d(z,w), where z,wâˆˆZğ‘§ğ‘¤ğ‘z,w\in Z, zâ‰ wğ‘§ğ‘¤z\neq w. Observe that the Vietoris-Rips complex Rtsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡R_{t} does not change when tğ‘¡t runs within Î”Î”\Delta. Take such a tğ‘¡t, and assume that the parameter Î»>1ğœ†1\lambda>1 is close to 111 so that

(t/Î»,Î»â€‹t)âŠ‚Î”.ğ‘¡ğœ†ğœ†ğ‘¡Î”(t/\lambda,\lambda t)\subset\Delta\;. (12)

Recall that Î»ğœ†\lambda appears in assumption (â™ â™ \spadesuit) on supports of functions fz(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘§f^{(t)}_{z}, zâˆˆZğ‘§ğ‘z\in Z from the partitions of unity; these functions play the role of probabilities in our registration model. Roughly speaking, Î»ğœ†\lambda measures deviation of the support from the metric ball Bâ€‹(z,t)ğµğ‘§ğ‘¡B(z,t). The proof of Proposition 4.2 together with inclusion (12) yield

Rt/Î»âŠ‚CtâŠ‚Rtâ€‹Î»,subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡ğœ†subscriptğ¶ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡ğœ†R_{t/\lambda}\subset C_{t}\subset R_{t\lambda}\;, (13)

and hence, since Rt/Î»=Rt=Rtâ€‹Î»subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡ğœ†subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡ğœ†R_{t/\lambda}=R_{t}=R_{t\lambda}, we conclude that Ct=Rtsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡C_{t}=R_{t}.

Sometimes, for an individual value of the parameter, the Rips complex associated to a finite subset carries important topological information about the ambient manifold. For instance, by a theorem of Latschev [13], for every sufficiently small t>0ğ‘¡0t>0 there exists r>0ğ‘Ÿ0r>0 such that Rtsubscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡R_{t} is homotopically equivalent to Mğ‘€M for every rğ‘Ÿr-net Zğ‘Z in Mğ‘€M. Take such tğ‘¡t, and choose r>0ğ‘Ÿ0r>0 small enough so that tâˆˆğ’¥ğ‘¡ğ’¥t\in{\mathcal{J}} and Latschevâ€™s theorem holds. Choosing Zğ‘Z to be a generic r/2ğ‘Ÿ2r/2-net, we can achieve that tâˆ‰Î“ğ‘¡Î“t\notin\Gamma. Next, pick Î»>1ğœ†1\lambda>1 so close to 111 that Ct=Rtsubscriptğ¶ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘…ğ‘¡C_{t}=R_{t}. Finally, assume that (â™¢â™¢\diamondsuit) holds for tğ‘¡t, which, for instance, holds when the boundaries of the supports of the functions fz(t)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘“ğ‘¡ğ‘§f^{(t)}_{z} are smooth and intersect transversally. Then (11) guarantees that for a given mğ‘šm and a sufficiently small â„Planck-constant-over-2-pi\hbar we have Qm,â„,t=Ctsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘šPlanck-constant-over-2-piğ‘¡subscriptğ¶ğ‘¡Q_{m,\hbar,t}=C_{t}. This yields that, for specially chosen sensor nets Zğ‘Z and for Î»ğœ†\lambda sufficiently close to 111, the quantum complex Qm,â„,tsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘šPlanck-constant-over-2-piğ‘¡Q_{m,\hbar,t} has the homotopy type of Mğ‘€M. Let us mention that in this case we got a stronger conclusion without applying the stability theorem for persistence modules which plays a crucial role in our proof of Theorem 3.3.

However, for the values of Î»ğœ†\lambda which are large in comparison with the ratios of the consecutive points in Î“Î“\Gamma, the above argument fails since â€œsandwichingâ€ (13) does not allow one to detect topology of the classical complex Cğ¶C in terms of the Vietoris-Rips complex Rğ‘…R. At this point the stability theorem enters the play, and we do not see a shortcut.

5 Registration: proofs

Derivation of formula (1): Preparation of a system in the classical state Î½ğœˆ\nu means choosing an Mğ‘€M-valued random variable Zğ‘Z which is uniformly distributed with respect to Î½ğœˆ\nu, i.e., the probability of finding Zğ‘Z in a subset UâŠ‚Mğ‘ˆğ‘€U\subset M equals Î½â€‹(U)ğœˆğ‘ˆ\nu(U). 7 Discussion and further directions

The subject of the present note is related to manifold learning, a technique of inferring topology of low-dimensional submanifolds of â„nsuperscriptâ„ğ‘›{\mathbb{R}}^{n} from sufficiently dense samples (see e.g. [18]). The motivation comes from dimensionality reduction in data analysis. While closed symplectic manifolds (i.e., phase spaces) do not naturally arise as submanifolds of linear spaces, many interesting examples appear as the Marsden-Weinstein reduction of symplectic manifolds equipped with a Hamiltonian Lie group action [16]. It would be interesting to explore whether topology of a reduced phase space can be reconstructed from quantum data.

It is tempting to apply the technique of the present note to the tunneling effect discussed in the introduction. Assume that we are given a classical Hamiltonian gğ‘”g on Mğ‘€M. Let Î¾â„subscriptğœ‰Planck-constant-over-2-pi\xi_{\hbar} be a generic linear combination of pure eigenstates of the quantum Hamiltonian Tâ„â€‹(g)subscriptğ‘‡Planck-constant-over-2-piğ‘”T_{\hbar}(g) with the eigenvalues from a sufficiently small neighborhood of Î»ğœ†\lambda, where Î»ğœ†\lambda is a regular value of gğ‘”g. Suppose that the initial state of the system equals Î¾â„subscriptğœ‰Planck-constant-over-2-pi\xi_{\hbar}. Can one infer homology of the level set {g=Î»}ğ‘”ğœ†\{g=\lambda\} from the statistics of consecutive registrations with respect to a sufficiently dense system of sensors?

Another natural question is whether one can infer symplectic topology of quantum phase space. While reconstructing the symplectic structure seems to be out of reach, one can detect certain quantum footprints of symplectic rigidity, see e.g. [21].

Can one recover the homotopy type of the quantum phase space? In this note we did this for quite special partitions of unity, see Sections 4.4 and 6, while for more general partitions considered in Section 3 we restricted ourselves to a modest topological information such as homology with coefficients in a field. Detecting the homotopy type in this generality might be plausible, cf. [13, 18], but seemingly requires new ideas.

Let us mention, for the record, that for the standard Berezin-Toeplitz quantization of closed KÃ¤hler manifolds the dimension of the quantum Hilbert space â„‹â„subscriptâ„‹Planck-constant-over-2-pi\mathcal{H}_{\hbar} is given by the Hirzebruch-Riemann-Roch formula [15] which carries certain topological information. For instance, if Mğ‘€M is a closed real surface of genus gğ‘”g equipped with a quantizable symplectic form,

dimâ„‹â„=Areaâ€‹(M)2â€‹Ï€â€‹â„+1âˆ’g.dimensionsubscriptâ„‹Planck-constant-over-2-piAreağ‘€2ğœ‹Planck-constant-over-2-pi1ğ‘”\dim\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}=\frac{\text{Area}(M)}{2\pi\hbar}+1-g\;.

However, I am unable to come up with any gedankenexperiment which enables one to detect dimâ„‹â„dimensionsubscriptâ„‹Planck-constant-over-2-pi\dim\mathcal{H}_{\hbar}.

Finally, an intriguing link between topological data analysis and quantum mechanics, which goes another way around, appears in [14]. In this paper, the authors propose a quantum algorithm for calculating persistent homology. It would be interesting to implement it for inferring topology of a quantum phase space along the lines of Section 3 above. This might shed some light on how topological structures arise in an intrinsic way in matrix quantum mechanics.

Appendix A Toeplitz operators with piecewise constant symbol (by Laurent Charles)

Theorem A.2.
  1. 1.

  2. 2.
